rsbNotes.title: 2 Chr 10–28
rsbNotes.text:
10:1–28:27 The Divided Kingdom. In this section the writer makes use of 1 Kin. 12–2 Kin. 17. His record of the period of the divided monarchy does not rehearse the harsh condemnation of the northern tribes found in Kings, focusing instead on events in Judah where the temple was and the Davidic king lived. Throughout this section, the writer reports how the conditions in the kingdom depended on the nation’s faithfulness to God. As readers considered these events, they could see clearly the choices for blessing and curse in their own day.

In telling about Rehoboam’s kingship, the writer makes broad use of Kings (cf. 10:1–11:4 with 1 Kin. 12:1–24; 12:9–16 with 1 Kin. 14:21, 25–31), while presenting the material in accord with his own theological understanding and emphasis. The account is presented in two parts (chs. 10; 11 and 12:1–14), each part narrating a problematic situation, prophetic encounter, and divine blessing. The conclusion is a notice of his wars with Jeroboam and his death (12:15, 16). The chapters impress on the readers God’s curse against pride and infidelity and the benefits of living in humility and obedience to the prophetic word (20:20 note).

rsbNotes.title: 2 Chr 22:10–24:27
rsbNotes.text: 22:10–24:27 Compare 2 Kin. chs. 11 and 12 on the record of Joash. This portion of Chronicles illustrates the close association between king and priest. The Davidic line was preserved by Jehoshabeath and her husband, the priest Jehoiada (22:10–23:21); the Davidic king served faithfully under the influence of Jehoiada (24:1–16); the king failed when he rejected the instruction of Jehoiada’s son, and put him to death (24:17–27). Cooperation of king and priest was essential. See also Zech. 3; 4; 6:9–15.

rsbNotes.title: 2 Chr 24:1–22
rsbNotes.text: 24:1–22 This account should be compared with 2 Kin. 12. Note that vv. 15–22 are a lengthy supplement.

rsbNotes.title: 2 Chr 24:2
rsbNotes.text: 24:2 all the days of Jehoiada. Joash’s positive accomplishments were the result of the influence of Jehoiada (24:14). After Jehoiada’s death, Joash turned away from the Lord (24:17–19; cf. 26:5). The historian illustrates the importance of mutual support between king and priest (22:10–24:27 note).

rsbNotes.title: 2 Chr 24:5
rsbNotes.text:
24:5 priests and the Levites. Chronicles more than 2 Kin. 12:1–3 emphasizes the need for proper Levitical order (23:18, 19 note).

money . . . from year to year. This requirement was the half-shekel tax of Ex. 30:11–16; 38:24–26 (see 24:9).

rsbNotes.title: 2 Chr 24:6, 9
rsbNotes.text: 24:6, 9 Moses . . . laid on Israel. See note 1 Chr. 16:40.

rsbNotes.title: 2 Chr 24:10–12
rsbNotes.text: 24:10–12 The generous and joyful giving of the officials and people was a good example for those engaged in restoring temple worship following the return from exile in Babylonia (1 Chr. 29:1–9 note).

rsbNotes.title: 2 Chr 24:19
rsbNotes.text: 24:19 prophets . . . they would not pay attention. Apostasy is tied to the rejection of God’s prophets (20:20 note).

rsbNotes.title: 2 Chr 24:20
rsbNotes.text: 24:20 you have forsaken . . . he has forsaken. See note 1 Chr. 28:9.

rsbNotes.title: 2 Chr 24:23–24
rsbNotes.text: 24:23, 24 Chronicles frequently mentions military defeat as the judgment of God against sin (1 Chr. 10; 2 Chr. 13:1–16; 18:33, 34; 21:16, 17; 25:14–24; 28:1–5; 33:1–11).

rsbNotes.title: 2 Chr 24:24
rsbNotes.text: 24:24 Judah had forsaken. The tables are turned against Judah as had been threatened in the covenant (Deut. 28:25; 32:30; 1 Chr. 28:9 note).

rsbNotes.title: 2 Chr 24:26
rsbNotes.text: 24:26 Ammonite . . . Moabite. Jehoshaphat had earlier defeated Ammon and Moab (20:1 note).

rsbNotes.title: 2 Chr 24:27
rsbNotes.text: 24:27 Story of the Book of the Kings. See Introduction to 1 Chronicles: Author.

rsbNotes.title: 2 Chr 25
rsbNotes.text: 25:1–28 The account of Amaziah’s reign (796–767 b.c.) should be compared with 2 Kin. 14. Note that the war against Edom is recorded only in Chronicles (vv. 5–16). The writer of Chronicles shows how foreign alliances, response to prophetic instruction, and idolatry affect Israel’s military security. The account describes fidelity and infidelity, much as in the accounts of Joash and Uzziah (22:10–24:27 note).

rsbNotes.title: 2 Chr 25:1–13
rsbNotes.text: 25:1–13 Ahaziah was not devoted wholeheartedly to the Lord, but he responded properly to prophetic warning (20:20 note).

rsbNotes.title: 2 Chr 25:4
rsbNotes.text: 25:4 Book of Moses. See 1 Chr. 16:40.

rsbNotes.title: 2 Chr 25:5–6
rsbNotes.text: 25:5, 6 300,000 . . . 100,000. For these large numbers, see note 1 Chr. 12:23.

rsbNotes.title: 2 Chr 25:7
rsbNotes.text:
25:7 do not let the army of Israel go. The prophet again condemns an alliance with the northern kingdom (16:2 note).

the Lord is not with Israel. Abijah had voiced a similar opinion concerning the northern kingdom (13:9, 10).

rsbNotes.title: 2 Chr 25:8
rsbNotes.text: 25:8 God has power. In typical fashion, the man of God proclaims the need to rely solely upon divine power in battle (16:2 note).

rsbNotes.title: 2 Chr 25:10
rsbNotes.text: 25:10 angry with Judah. Although Amaziah obeyed the prophetic word, the northern mercenaries were angry. If not their pay, they had lost their chance for booty (cf. v. 13).

rsbNotes.title: 2 Chr 25:12
rsbNotes.text: 25:12 all dashed to pieces. Amaziah followed Mosaic instructions for holy war (Deut. 20:13–18).

rsbNotes.title: 2 Chr 25:13
rsbNotes.text: 25:13 Samaria. An unidentified town in Judah, not the better-known capital of the northern kingdom.

rsbNotes.title: 2 Chr 25:14
rsbNotes.text: 25:14 brought the gods. In contrast with Amaziah’s earlier obedience (v. 12), he now disobeyed Mosaic instructions (Ex. 20:3; Deut. 7:25) and David’s example (1 Chr. 14:12), bringing the Edomite gods to Jerusalem. He eventually worshiped these gods.

rsbNotes.title: 2 Chr 25:15–16
rsbNotes.text: 25:15, 16 In contrast with his earlier repentance at the prophetic word (25:7–10), Amaziah rebuffed the prophet and received a stern warning (20:20 note).

rsbNotes.title: 2 Chr 25:16
rsbNotes.text: 25:16 God has determined to destroy you. See note 1 Chr. 28:9.

rsbNotes.title: 2 Chr 25:20
rsbNotes.text: 25:20 it was of God. The sovereignty of God includes hardening the hearts of sinners so that they no longer respond to warnings (1 Chr. 21:1 note; cf. Ex. 3:19; 4:12; 7:3, 4).

rsbNotes.title: 2 Chr 25:22–24
rsbNotes.text: 25:22–24 The defeat of Amaziah contrasts with his earlier victory (vv. 11–13).

rsbNotes.title: 2 Chr 25:26
rsbNotes.text: 25:26 Book of the Kings. See Introduction to 1 Chronicles: Author.
